This
On
Week
List
Fiction
SAVING FAITH, by David Baldacci. (Warner Vision, $7.99.) A man and a woman are caught in machinations of the F.B.I. involving corrupt forces in Washington.
THE POISONWOOD BIBLE, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.) Five female characters narrate a novel set in the Belgian Congo during that country's fight for independence.
MONSTER, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Alex Delaware undertakes to discover how an inmate of a mental hospital can correctly predict brutal murders on the streets of Los Angeles.
NIGHT TALES, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $14.95.) Four novels of romantic suspense that revolve around police officers and a prosecutor.
*A WALK TO REMEMBER, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $6.99.) In 1958, a high school senior in North Carolina finds love with the daughter of a Baptist minister.
LEFT BEHIND, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $13.99 and $7.99.) Life as lived by those who survive a global cataclysm. (+)
BLACK NOTICE, by Patricia Cornwell. (Berkley, $7.99.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta's investigation of a ship's cargo leads her into an international conspiracy.
A GOD IN RUINS, by Leon Uris. (Avon, $7.99.) On his way to the White House, Gov. Quinn Patrick O'Connell of Colorado discovers a secret that imperils his future.
HIGH TIDE, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) A New York businesswoman, on a trip to the Everglades, becomes a suspect in a murder case.
PLAINSONG, by Kent Haruf. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.) A half-dozen members of a high-plains Colorado community learn to contend with the variety of problems that face them.
*HARD TIME, by Sara Paretsky. (Dell, $6.99.) V. I. Warshawski copes with mysteries involving a multimedia conglomerate and a prison for women.
SILENT SNOW, by Steve Thayer. (Signet, $6.99.) The infant son of a Twin Cities reporter and an anchorwoman is abducted on the anniversary of the Lindbergh kidnapping.
WHILE I WAS GONE, by Sue Miller. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A small-town veterinarian, the wife of a minister, begins a flirtation with an old friend from her bohemian past.
THE ALIBI, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $7.99.) Jealousy, intrigue and corruption beset a Charleston lawyer during his pursuit of public office.
*HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) Five long, interconnected stories about an America haunted by the Vietnam War.

This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America: the second volume of a memoir.
THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
. . . AND NEVER LET HER GO, by Ann Rule. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) The murder of a secretary to the governor of Delaware by an esteemed attorney.
A MAN NAMED DAVE, by Dave Pelzer. (Plume, $11.) The concluding volume of a memoir that began with ''A Child Called 'It' ''and ''The Lost Boy.'' (+)
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived abuse at the hands of an unstable, alcoholic mother. (+)
THE TERRIBLE HOURS, by Peter Maas. (HarperTorch, $6.99.) The role a United States Navy officer played in rescuing the crew of a submarine in 1939.
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The story of the northeaster of 1991, focusing on a crew of fishermen from Gloucester, Mass.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life at a series of foster homes. (+)
SURVIVOR, by Mark Burnett with Martin Dugard. (TV Books, $17.95.) The companion volume to the television show.
ONE LAST TIME, by John Edward. (Berkley, $12.95.) A self-described psychic medium discusses his life and work.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $13.) A journalist finds beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor, $15.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy. (+)
THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $14.) A sea captain's account of her 30-day swordfishing voyage off the Northeast coast.
ISAAC'S STORM, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $13.) An account of America's deadliest hurricane, in Galveston, Tex., in 1900, and the Weather Bureau scientist who failed to forecast it.
*THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN, by Simon Winchester. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.) How a murderer and certified lunatic helped James Murray compile the Oxford English Dictionary.

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson. (Putnam, $19.95.) How to deal with changes at work and in life in general. (+)
GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS 2001. (Guinness, $26.95.) A profusely illustrated collection of records about subjects as various as sports and technology.
BODY FOR LIFE, by Bill Phillips with Michael D'Orso. (HarperCollins, $26.) Ways to improve one's body and one's life. (+)
LIFE MAKEOVERS, by Cheryl Richardson. (Broadway, $21.95.) How to improve one's life a week at a time. (+)
RELATIONSHIP RESCUE, by Phillip C. McGraw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A program for reconnecting with one's partner. (+)

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
TALKING DIRTY WITH THE QUEEN OF CLEAN, by Linda Cobb. (Pocket Books, $8.99.) A housekeeping guide.
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
THE FOUR AGREEMENTS, by Don Miguel Ruiz. (Amber-Allen, $12.95.) A code of conduct based on personal freedom. (+)
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $6.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
TAKE TIME FOR YOUR LIFE, by Cheryl Richardson. (Broadway, $13.) A seven-step program for enhancing social, financial and spiritual well-being. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Sept. 30, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
